Stricter penalties can potentially discourage financial institutions from engaging in unethical or illegal activities. the threat of heavy fines, revocation of licenses, and legal actions can serve as a deterrent, as evidenced by the recent fines levied against some financial institutions for various violations.

however, financial institutions are complex entities, and several factors can drive their behavior. some financial institutions may prioritize profits over responsibility, and penalties may not always deter them. thus, it is crucial to promote transparency, enforce ethical business practices, and create more stringent regulatory frameworks.

the implementation of these measures, combined with appropriate penalties, may help establish a culture of responsibility and ethics in the financial industry, which can minimize the likelihood of future financial crises. additionally, the cooperation of multiple stakeholders, including regulators, policymakers, and financial institutions, will be critical in implementing and enforcing regulatory frameworks and holding those who violate them accountable.

repeated violations of regulations and laws should result in heavier fines and stricter legal action, and authorities should ensure that such penalties are meaningful and proportionate to the harm caused. by enforcing appropriate penalties and stricter regulations, the financial industry can be held more accountable for its actions, and this, in turn, can help prevent future financial crises.
